title: Savers cheer as Isa rates rise: top one-year account now pays 1.85pc
text:
Print 
Tax-free returns improve on one and two-year accounts as competition gathers momentum 
Rates on tax-free savings improved this week after Shawbrook Bank and Virgin Money launched best-buy one and two-year cash Isas. 
Shawbrook now offers a one-year cash Isa paying 1.85pc, better than the previous market-leader, from Julian Hodge Bank, which had paid 1.8pc. 
There is a minimum £5,000 deposit but transfers from previous years are accepted. You can open the account online and withdrawing cash early will result in the loss of 90 days’ interest on the money. 
• Predictions on rates, stock markets and much more: get our weekly newsletter 
Virgin Money’s two-year cash Isa pays 2.06pc, an improvement on the previous best-buy from Halifax that pays 2pc. 
Virgin also launched an accompanying two-year savings bond, for money outside an Isa, that pays 2.06pc but the rate is some way off the best-buy in that category 2.35pc offered by RCI Bank, Aldermore and Kent Reliance. 
Compeition among savings providers is heating up. Another challenger to the high street giants, RCI Bank, this week launched a three-year bond paying 2.7pc - beating the current best deal by a larger margin than is usual. 
Tom Adams, head of research at savings adviser Savingschampion.co.uk, said: “Just as we were thinking that the recent flurry of new best buy fixed rate ISAs was starting to subside, in swooped two of the most active providers in this category in recent times with a couple of market leading accounts. 
“What is particularly pleasing about these changes is that both providers were already well placed in the best buy tables, with Virgin joint top and Shawbrook in joint second place and they were not content with this, wanting to stand out from the pack. 
"Long may this type of move continue, as it is pushing rates back in the right direction and hopefully other providers will follow suit.”
